tutorial.moduleOverview: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. In this tutorial, you will learn about the fundamentals of Node.js and how to create fast web servers using event-driven programming.
learningObjectives: Understand what Node.js is and its advantages
Learn about the platform architecture of Node.js
Explore the industry support and open-source libraries for Node.js
Learn about the components of a web application's backend and how to use Node.js for web servers

introduction.heading: What is Node.js?
introduction.paragraph: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine. It allows developers to write server-side code in JavaScript, enabling the development of fast web servers using event-driven programming.

introduction.heading: Platform Architecture
introduction.paragraph: Node.js enables the development of fast web servers in JavaScript using event-driven programming. It simplifies server development by using callbacks to signal the completion of tasks, avoiding the need for threading.

introduction.heading: Industry Support
introduction.paragraph: There are thousands of open-source libraries for Node.js, hosted on the npm website. Node.js connects the ease of JavaScript with the power of Unix network programming, making it accessible to the web development community.

introduction.heading: Components of Web Application Backend
introduction.paragraph: Node.js allows the creation of web servers and networking tools using JavaScript, along with modules that handle core functionalities like file system I/O, networking, cryptography functions, and more.
